stream_context.summary: Kaze returns to Twitch after a long break and sets up multistreaming (Twitch + YouTube) via Restream. Development-wise, he works on Course 11’s retro “8-bit section” inspired by Smash 64’s Board the Platforms: iterating on the signature floating-square background, weighing performance tradeoffs (overdraw/transparency), fixing a rendering/logic bug in rotation direction, and beginning a blockout pass for the platform layout. He also shares broader production context (moved houses, full-time job at Gears for Breakfast, NDA anxiety, remaining world theme plans, and camera-control tuning based on player feedback).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a workflow shift (return to Twitch + multistream), reveals late-project roadmap (only four world themes left), and captures a concrete design/tech iteration cycle for a major retro set-piece (Smash 64 background) including performance constraints and a key bug-fix moment.

findings.summary: Kaze returns to Twitch and begins multistreaming to Twitch and YouTube using Restream, aiming to combine audiences and increase chat activity/engagement; he notes Twitch’s TOS now allows multistreaming.

He explicitly frames multistreaming as beneficial for reach and engagement, joking about making Twitch and YouTube audiences ‘fight’ for engagement; he also notes Twitch subscriptions as direct income and that some viewers stayed subbed while he was gone.

For Course 11’s retro section, Kaze commits to a Smash 64 Board the Platforms-inspired segment rendered in 3D. He lists remaining retro inspirations he plans to use next: Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, and Mario Land 1, noting the team is ‘almost out of retro games’ and is stretching the definition up to N64-era.
Kaze says Badub has already delivered songs for the game’s areas and that the tracks are consistently strong (“bangers”).

He evaluates multiple approaches for the Smash-style floating-square background and rejects scrolling textured layers due to severe overdraw cost on N64-style rendering; he estimates full-screen overdraw can be ~5ms per layer, making 4 layers ~20ms and unacceptable.
Fast64’s viewport doesn’t accurately represent N64 transparency, so he relies on in-game trial-and-error to match Smash’s look (notably the ‘white’ translucent squares).

He pivots from modeling many individual 3D squares to using a high-poly skysphere with the square shapes drawn/cut into it (a ‘Tetris’ cutout workflow), then adds layered spheres and implements slow rotation via geo nodes exported from Fast64.
findings.quote: This is the stupidest thing ever, but it works.

findings.summary: A rotation-direction bug is traced to order-of-operations; a chat member points out the likely cause, and Kaze confirms the fix immediately improves the behavior.
Kaze identifies and fixes a visual artifact caused by bubble-related code using undefined vertices (a quick, contained bug fix).

He blockouts early platforming for the Board the Platforms section (four outward paths concept, adding moving up/down platforms). He adjusts platform sizes and landing areas to avoid unfair jumps, while keeping optional difficulty since it’s Course 11.

He shares late-project world planning: only four major level themes remain, including a planned ‘Wild West Valley’ with villain/boss-capture encounters, a potential music-themed world (currently no ideas), an oversized casino world (no ideas), and a comic-book city world with superhero Mario hunting/fighting villains.
He mentions he recently moved into a new house (showing his workout/stream space and a large ‘Yoshi wall’), and he’s juggling development with a full-time job.
He describes anxiety around an NDA at his day job, including a nightmare about accidentally breaking it and being interrogated by ‘Gus Fring.’
findings.quote: I had a nightmare today that I accidentally broke our NDA and Gus Fring came to me and interrogated me about me breaking my NDA.

findings.summary: Camera control feedback: he defends his d-pad camera behavior (small adjustments that accelerate if held), then prototypes new velocity/acceleration parameters to make tap adjustments feel more consistent without adding more options-menu clutter.
Stream alerts/points/redemptions appear partially broken during multistream; he misses a major donation because the alert did not fire and flags it as something he needs to fix.

badub.summary: Kaze reiterates that Badub has already produced songs for all the areas shown so far and that the OST quality is consistently high.

zeina.summary: Zeina messages early that Twitch streaming works again, and later says goodbye in chat; Kaze references watching Spirited Away with her (as context for his opinion).

findings.summary: Catx helps Kaze identify that the Smash background rotation issue is caused by order-of-operations; once corrected, the rotation behaves as intended and Kaze expresses relief.
A 200-euro donation comes in but is noticed ~30 minutes late due to broken alerts; Kaze reacts strongly and says it materially helps.

key_stories.title: Returning to Twitch via multistream after months on YouTube
key_stories.summary: Kaze reopens Twitch as a platform after avoiding it due to ads, then adopts Restream to broadcast to both Twitch and YouTube. The move reframes streaming as both development documentation and audience-building, while introducing new operational issues (alert integrations, redemptions, chat UX).
key_stories.challenge: He wanted Twitch back without dealing with ads, and wanted to reach both audiences without choosing one platform.
key_stories.process: Finds a workaround for the ad experience, tests Restream live, merges chats on-screen, and compares historical viewership (Twitch ~100 vs YouTube ~50) to the combined total.
key_stories.outcome: He concludes the ‘dual setup’ is cozy and effective, but discovers broken alerts/redemptions that cause missed events (including a major donation).

key_stories.title: Smash 64 ‘Board the Platforms’ background: from 3D squares to textured skyspheres
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to recreate the iconic Smash 64 target-test backdrop inside RTYI’s 3D space. The segment becomes a full micro-arc of iteration: identifying what looks wrong, what is too expensive on N64-style hardware, and finally landing on a layered skysphere approach with controlled rotation.
key_stories.challenge: Make the background feel like Smash 64 (layered translucent squares) while keeping performance acceptable and matching N64 transparency behavior.
key_stories.process: He rejects a scrolling-texture approach due to overdraw cost, experiments with 3D squares and layering, then switches to cutting square shapes into UV spheres and exporting rotation nodes via Fast64. He debugs rotation direction and speed, eventually tracing a key issue to order-of-operations.
key_stories.outcome: He reaches a convincing ‘vibe’ match and establishes workable rotation speeds for three layers, then moves on to platform blockout and remaining aesthetic details (bottom fade/black-hole look).
key_stories.key_quote: This is the stupidest thing ever, but it works.

key_stories.title: Camera control feedback leads to parameter-level tuning (without adding options)
key_stories.summary: A viewer critiques d-pad micro-adjustments feeling too smoothed/accelerated. Kaze explains his intent—d-pad should serve both fine adjustments and full camera rotation—then iterates on velocity/acceleration to improve tap consistency without bloating the options menu.
key_stories.challenge: Balance two player needs: precise tap adjustments vs holding for continuous camera rotation, while avoiding an overly complex settings menu.
key_stories.process: He demonstrates current behavior, discusses why acceleration exists, then tries new base velocity and reduced acceleration values to keep quick taps more predictable while remaining usable for slower players.
key_stories.outcome: He settles on a tentative tuning that feels ‘fast enough for bad players’ but still allows alignment, with the expectation he’ll test and revise if needed.

open_questions.topic: Final four world themes and idea gaps (music world, casino world)
open_questions.context: Kaze says only four major level themes remain; Wild West Valley is more defined, while the music and casino worlds have ‘no ideas’ yet. A ‘Yoshi school’ suggestion briefly excites him as an alternative direction.
questions: When did you realize you were down to the last four themes—was that planned pacing, or did the scope naturally shrink to a finishable set?
What’s the core gameplay ‘hook’ you imagine for Wild West Valley’s detective/bounty structure—how do boss captures differ from typical Mario 64 stars?
What makes a ‘music world’ feel worthy of RTYI (mechanically, not just aesthetically), and what ideas have you rejected so far?
You reacted strongly to the idea of a ‘Yoshi school.’ What about that theme sparked inspiration, and could it replace the music world or become a sub-area?
For the oversized casino and comic-city worlds: what would you want players to *do* there moment-to-moment so they don’t become ‘theme-only’ levels?

open_questions.topic: Smash-style background polish decisions (fade, rotation, render order)
open_questions.context: After achieving a strong match, Kaze still dislikes aspects like the bottom transition/fade and how ‘too perfect’ edges look compared to Smash’s fuzzier low-res texture feel.
questions: What’s your final target for the bottom of the scene—fade to black, fade to blue, or a deliberate ‘black hole’ void—and what will decide it?
How much are you willing to deviate from Smash authenticity (e.g., adding slow spin) if it improves the 3D feel or readability?
At what point do you stop iterating on ‘vibe accuracy’ and lock the art direction to protect schedule?
What N64 performance budget are you using as a rule of thumb for this effect (tri counts, overdraw, fill rate), and how close are you to it now?

open_questions.topic: Multistream operational impact (alerts, redemptions, community rituals)
open_questions.context: Alerts/redemptions appear unreliable during the first Restream test; Kaze misses a large donation for ~30 minutes and notes he can’t easily track point redemptions like song requests.
questions: What streaming ‘rituals’ (song requests, point redeems, on-screen alerts) matter most to you for community culture, and which ones are you willing to drop if multistream complicates them?
After missing the 200-euro donation, did you change any tooling or monitoring so big moments can’t slip by again?
Has multistream changed how you pace development on-stream—more explaining for newcomers, fewer deep technical dives, or the opposite?
